Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Multi-Spacecraft Investigation of Hot Flow Anomalies
Award.AbstractNarration:
Hot Flow Anomalies (HFAs) are phenomena observed near the Earth's bow shock that are marked by strongly heated plasmas and substantial deflections in the plasma flow direction. The objective of the proposed research is to determine the characteristics of HFAs, understand how particle heating occurs inside HFAs, and determine their impact on the magnetosphere and ionosphere. The first year will be a systematic survey of hot flow anomaly events to determine the characteristics of HFAs observed upstream of the bow shock and in the magnetosheath. During the second year, the project will determine how the electrons and ions are heated and how the energetic particles (>25 keV) are accelerated inside HFAs. During the third year, the impact of HFAs on the magnetosphere and ionosphere will be determined. The project will use a variety of data sets including data from the THEMIS, Cluster and Geotail spacecraft when they were located near the bow shock.

The significance of the proposed work lies in the fundamental information it will provide about HFAs, which can significantly modify the solar wind-magnetosphere interaction, generate shocks, and energize particles efficiently. The study will advance our understanding of the structure and characteristics of HFAs, the physics underlying particle heating inside HFAs, and their impact on the magnetosphere and ionosphere. The interaction between the solar wind and the magnetosphere is a key element in space physics.

This study will form the core of the Ph.D. thesis for a graduate student from an underrepresented minority at the Center for Atmospheric Research, University of Massachusetts, Lowell. The scientific results will be highlighted on the THEMIS science nugget website which was developed for members of the public who are interested in THEMIS science results but may not have space physics backgrounds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hot flow anomalies (HFAs) are kinetic phenomena occurred near planetary bow shocks that are marked by greatly heated solar wind plasmas and substantial flow deflection (and sometimes even flows backward toward the Sun). HFAs may have a substantial impact on the solar windmagnetosphere-ionosphere interaction because they drive magnetopause boundary waves, modulate electron precipitation, trigger auroral brightenings or dimmings, excite ULF waves within the magnetospheric cavity, drive field-aligned currents, and initiate high-latitude ionospheric magnetic impulse events. The objective of this project is to determine the characteristics of HFAs, understand how particle heating occurs inside HFAs, and determine their impact on the magnetosphere and ionosphere.

 

The first major finding of this project is the discovery of the spontaneous HFAs. We found that HFAs can be generated spontaneously at the quasi-parallel shocks, which challenges our current understanding of HFAs because HFAs are thought to be produced by the interaction of solar wind current sheets with the bow shock. Observations of the spontaneous HFAs are significant because they indicate the need for a significant modification to our current understanding of the solar wind-magnetosphere interaction. More specifically, the response of planetary magnetosphere and ionosphere to solar wind input can be very dynamic even for steady solar wind plasma and IMF conditions. The second major finding of this project concerns how ions and electrons are heated inside HFAs. By analyzing measurements from the THEMIS mission, we demonstrated that electromagnetic right-hand resonant ion beam instabilities heat ions inside HFAs. The electrostatic waves are the source of the electron heating inside HFAs. The third major finding is how HFAs evolve with time. With multiple THEMIS spacecraft observations, we found the earliest stage of HFAs (named “proto-HFAs”). We showed that HFA evolution can be divided into three stages: proto, young, and mature stages.

 

HFAs are universal phenomena that are associated with shock waves in plasmas that are found in many environments, from the solar atmosphere to distant galaxies. Therefore the findings from this project have broad scientific impact. Results from this proposal provide a better understanding of kinetic processes in a collisionless plasma. Results obtained by this project can be applied to any shock.

 

A total of 8 papers have been published in peer-reviewed journals. In addition, 17 presentations (5 invited) were given at scientific conferences. Also, we have organized a special issue “Magnetospheric Response to Solar Wind Discontinuities” in the Journal of Atmospheric and Solar-Terrestrial Physics (Volume 73, Issue 1). The PI and Co-I of this project (and 2 co-Chairs) lead a NSF GEM focus group titled "Transient Phenomena at the Magnetopause and Bow Shock and Their Ground Signatures”. A table and a short description of some transient foreshock phenomena, together with a list of HFA and Foreshock Bubble events with summary plots has been posted on the GEM wiki page, which is accessible to the community.

 

This project promotes teaching, training and learning by engaging a graduate student and an undergraduate student in the work. Both the graduate student and the PI involved are female members of under-represented groups. This project integrates research and education. The PI is a junior faculty at the University of Alaska Fairbanks. This project also contributes to curriculum development in plasma physics and magnetospheric physics.
